title: United States foreign policy toward the People's Republic of China
text:
The <a href="foreign%20policy%20of%20the%20United%20States">United States foreign policy</a> toward the <a href="China">People's Republic of China</a> originated during the <a href="Cold%20War">Cold War</a>. At that time, the U.S. had a <a href="containment">containment</a> policy against <a href="communist%20state">communist state</a>s. The leaked "<a href="Pentagon%20Papers">Pentagon Papers</a>" indicated the efforts by the U.S. to contain China through military actions undertaken in the <a href="Vietnam%20War">Vietnam War</a>. President <a href="Richard%20Nixon">Richard Nixon</a>'s <a href="Richard%20Nixon%27s%201972%20visit%20to%20China">China rapprochement</a> signaled a shift in focus to gain leverage in containing the <a href="Soviet%20Union">Soviet Union</a>. Formal diplomatic ties between the U.S. and China were established in 1979, and with normalized trade relations since 2000, the U.S. and China have been linked by closer economic ties and more cordial relations.
During the 2010s and early 2020s, there was a significant shift in America's China policy. In his first term as <a href="U.S.%20president">U.S. president</a>, <a href="Barack%20Obama">Barack Obama</a> said, "We want China to succeed and prosper. It's good for the United States if China continues on the path of development that it's on." The Trump administration stated, "The United States recognizes the long-term strategic competition between our two systems." The <a href="presidency%20of%20Joe%20Biden">Biden administration</a> stated that previous optimistic approaches to China were flawed, and that China poses "the most significant challenge of any nation-state in the world to the United States". However, the <a href="US%20National%20Security%20Advisor">US National Security Advisor</a>, <a href="Jake%20Sullivan">Jake Sullivan</a>, has stated that the Biden administration does not pursue a fundamental transformation of the Chinese political system.
U.S. military presence in the region, efforts to improve relations with <a href="India%E2%80%93United%20States%20relations">India</a> and <a href="United%20States%E2%80%93Vietnam%20relations">Vietnam</a>, and the <a href="presidency%20of%20Barack%20Obama">Obama administration</a>'s 2012 <a href="East%20Asian%20foreign%20policy%20of%20the%20Barack%20Obama%20administration">"Pivot to Asia" strategy</a> for increased American involvement in the Western <a href="Pacific%20Ocean">Pacific</a>, have been associated with a policy aimed at countering China's growing clout. The <a href="Presidency%20of%20Donald%20Trump">Trump administration</a> designated China as a "<a href="revisionist%20state">revisionist power</a>" seeking to overturn the <a href="liberal%20international%20order">liberal international order</a> and displace the United States, and called for a <a href="whole-of-government%20approach">whole-of-government approach</a> to China guided by a return to principled <a href="realism%20%28international%20relations%29">realism</a>. Current U.S. military presence in the region includes military alliances <a href="Mutual%20Defense%20Treaty%20%28United%20States%E2%80%93South%20Korea%29">with</a> <a href="South%20Korea">South Korea</a>, <a href="Security%20Treaty%20Between%20the%20United%20States%20and%20Japan">with</a> <a href="Japan">Japan</a>, and <a href="Mutual%20Defense%20Treaty%20%28United%20States%E2%80%93Philippines%29">with</a> the <a href="Philippines">Philippines</a>.
Background.
Cold War era.
During the <a href="Cold%20War">Cold War</a> the United States tried to prevent the <a href="domino%20theory">domino theory</a> of the spread of <a href="communism">communism</a> and thwart communist countries including the People's Republic of China. Revelations about the motives behind the <a href="Vietnam%20War">US intervention in Vietnam</a> and the widening of covert combat operations to nearby <a href="Cambodia">Cambodia</a> and <a href="Laos">Laos</a> were leaked in the "<a href="Pentagon%20Papers">Pentagon Papers</a>" by <a href="Daniel%20Ellsberg">Daniel Ellsberg</a> in 1971.
Although President <a href="Lyndon%20B.%20Johnson">Lyndon B. Johnson</a> stated that the aim of the Vietnam War was to secure an "independent, non-Communist <a href="South%20Vietnam">South Vietnam</a>", a January 1965 <a href="memorandum">memorandum</a> by <a href="Secretary%20of%20Defense">Secretary of Defense</a> <a href="Robert%20McNamara">Robert McNamara</a> stated that an underlying justification was "not to help a friend, but to contain China". McNamara accused Red China of harboring <a href="imperialism">imperialist</a> aspirations like those of <a href="Nazi%20Germany">Nazi Germany</a> and <a href="Imperial%20Japan">Imperial Japan</a>. According to him, China was conspiring to "organize all of Asia" against the United States.
As laid out by McNamara, the China containment policy of the United States was a long-run strategic effort to surround <a href="Beijing">Beijing</a> with the <a href="Soviet%20Union">USSR</a>, its <a href="satellite%20state">satellite state</a>s, as well as: (a) the <a href="Japan">Japan</a>–<a href="Korea">Korea</a> front, (b) the <a href="India">India</a>–<a href="Pakistan">Pakistan</a> front, and (c) the <a href="Southeast%20Asia">Southeast Asia</a> front.
Post-Cold War.
In more contemporary times, with the <a href="Richard%20Nixon%27s%201972%20visit%20to%20China">Nixon rapprochement</a> and the signing of the <a href="Shanghai%20Communiqu%C3%A9">Shanghai Communiqué</a>, improvement in U.S.-Sino relations was made possible. Formal diplomatic ties were established in 1979, and with normalized trade relations since 2000, the US and China have been linked by closer economic ties.
The United States' 2006 <a href="Quadrennial%20Defense%20Review">Quadrennial Defense Review</a> stated that China has "the greatest potential to compete militarily with the United States and field disruptive military technologies that could over time offset traditional U.S. military advantages absent U.S. counter strategies". The 2006 <a href="National%20Security%20Strategy%20%28United%20States%29">National Security Strategy</a> stated that the U.S. wanted China to continue down the road of <a href="Chinese%20economic%20reform">reform and openness</a>. It said that as economic growth continues, China would face a growing demand from its own people to follow the path of East Asia's many modern democracies, adding <a href="political%20freedom">political freedom</a> to <a href="economic%20freedom">economic freedom</a>. The document continues by stating that China cannot stay on this peaceful path while holding on to "old ways of thinking and acting" that exacerbate regional and international security concerns. The U.S. referred to the "old ways" in terms of non-transparent military expansion, <a href="mercantilism">mercantilism</a>, and supporting resource-rich regimes with a record of unacceptable behavior.
The United States' political leadership began to shift policy stances in 2011, starting with the <a href="Obama%20administration">Obama administration</a>'s "pivot" toward Asia. Then-<a href="United%20States%20Secretary%20of%20State">secretary of state</a> <a href="Hillary%20Clinton">Hillary Clinton</a> called for "increased investment—diplomatic, economic, strategic, and otherwise—in the Asia-Pacific region", which was seen as a move to counter China's growing clout. Supporters of increased American involvement in <a href="East%20Asia">East Asia</a> have cited the United States as a counterbalance to the excesses of Chinese expansion. Relevant to the argument is the fact that countries in territorial disputes with China, such as in the <a href="South%20China%20Sea">South China Sea</a> and the <a href="Senkaku%20Islands">Senkaku Islands</a>, have complained about China's harassment in the disputed areas. Some experts have suggested that China may leverage their economic strength in such disputes, one example being the sudden restriction on Chinese imports of Filipino bananas during tensions over the <a href="Scarborough%20Shoal">Scarborough Shoal</a>.
Recent development.
In April 2019, the fourth iteration of the influential <a href="neoconservative">neoconservative</a> think tank, the <a href="Committee%20on%20the%20Present%20Danger">Committee on the Present Danger</a>, was unveiled, calling itself the "Committee on the Present Danger: China (CPDC)" in a press conference in <a href="Washington%20DC">Washington DC</a>. The organization was reformed by former Trump administration White House Chief Strategist <a href="Steve%20Bannon">Steve Bannon</a> and former <a href="Reagan%20administration">Reagan administration</a> official <a href="Frank%20Gaffney">Frank Gaffney</a> to "educate and inform American citizens and policymakers about the existential threats presented from the Peoples Republic of China under the misrule of the <a href="Chinese%20Communist%20Party">Chinese Communist Party</a>". The CPDC takes the view that there is "no hope of coexistence with China as long as the Communist Party governs the country". <a href="Charles%20W.%20Freeman%20Jr.">Charles W. Freeman Jr.</a> at the <a href="Watson%20Institute">Watson Institute</a> called the CPDC "a "<a href="Who%27s%20Who">Who's Who</a>" of contemporary <a href="wingnut%20%28politics%29">wing-nut</a>s, very few of whom have any expertise at all about China and most of whom represent ideological causes only peripherally connected to it."
In a May 2019 opinion piece published by "<a href="Foreign%20Policy">Foreign Policy</a>", <a href="Paul%20Musgrave">Paul Musgrave</a>, an assistant professor at the <a href="University%20of%20Massachusetts%20Amherst">University of Massachusetts Amherst</a> commented that the <a href="Trump%20administration">Trump administration</a> revealed details about a long-term strategy in dealing with the <a href="rise%20of%20China">rise of China</a> via a "<a href="%3Awikt%3Aslip%20of%20the%20tongue">slip</a>" by then-director of policy planning <a href="Kiron%20Skinner">Kiron Skinner</a> at the <a href="United%20States%20Department%20of%20State">US State Department</a>. In a speech at the Future Security Forum on April 29, 2019, Skinner characterized the Cold War as "a huge fight within the Western family" and due to that shared heritage and value-system, breakthroughs could be made; on China however, she argued there can be no accommodation or cooperation because it is "... a fight with a really different civilization and a different ideology" and "it's the first time that we will have a great-power competitor that is not <a href="Caucasian%20race">Caucasian</a>".
A study on China produced by a small working group within the department led by Skinner reportedly envisioned a world of constant, unavoidable civilizational conflict. The study was informally called "Letter X" in reference to <a href="George%20F.%20Kennan">George F. Kennan</a>'s <a href="X%20Article">X Article</a> that advocated for a containment strategy against the <a href="Soviet%20Union">Soviet Union</a>. In August 2019, "<a href="The%20New%20York%20Times">The New York Times</a>" reported that Skinner had been forced out of her job at the Department of State, and that Trump administration officials privately dismissed her comments. Earlier in the year, an open letter titled "China is not an enemy" was released by five China-focused scholars and foreign policy experts, and was endorsed by some business leaders, in which they decried what they saw in the U.S. approach as "counterproductive", and urged the Trump administration to continue the more "cooperative" approach.
With questions about the continued purpose of the <a href="North%20Atlantic%20Treaty%20Organization">North Atlantic Treaty Organization</a> in a post-Cold War world, NATO countries have refrained from re-orienting toward and labeling the PRC an outright "enemy", but NATO chief <a href="Jens%20Stoltenberg">Jens Stoltenberg</a> said the organization needs to recognize the "challenges" posed by China at a NATO event in 2019, saying "China will soon have the world's biggest economy. And it already has the second largest defense budget, investing heavily in new capabilities." He also said that NATO did not want to "create new adversaries". The United States' NATO representative at the event referred to China as a "competitor".
On May 20, 2020, in accordance with the <a href="John%20S.%20McCain%20National%20Defense%20Authorization%20Act%20for%20Fiscal%20Year%202019">John S. McCain National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2019</a>, the Trump administration delivered a report, "U.S. Strategic Approach to the People's Republic of China" to members of the <a href="U.S.%20Congress">U.S. Congress</a>. The report states a <a href="whole-of-government%20approach">whole-of-government approach</a> to China under the <a href="National%20Security%20Strategy%20%28United%20States%29%232017%20NSS">2017 National Security Strategy</a>, which says it is time the U.S. "rethink the failed policies of the past two decades – policies based on the assumption that engagement with rivals and their inclusion in international institutions and global commerce would turn them into benign actors and trustworthy partners". The report says it "reflects a fundamental reevaluation of how the United States understands and responds to" the leaders of China, adding "The United States recognizes the long-term strategic competition between our two systems."
In February 2021, <a href="U.S.%20president">U.S. president</a> <a href="Joe%20Biden">Joe Biden</a> said that China is the "most serious competitor" that poses challenges on the "prosperity, security, and democratic values" of the U.S. <a href="United%20States%20Secretary%20of%20State">U.S. secretary of state</a> <a href="Antony%20Blinken">Antony Blinken</a> stated that previous optimistic approaches to China were flawed, and that China poses "the most significant challenge of any nation-state in the world to the United States". Blinken also agreed that Biden's predecessor, <a href="Donald%20Trump">Donald Trump</a>, "was right in taking a tougher approach to China".
In April 2021, the <a href="U.S.%20Senate">U.S. Senate</a> introduced major legislation in response to China's growing clout in international affairs. The bill, titled "Strategic Competition Act of 2021", reflects hardline attitude of both congressional Democrats and Republicans, and sets out to counter the Chinese government's diplomatic and strategic initiatives. <a href="Senate%20Foreign%20Relations%20Committee">Senate Foreign Relations Committee</a> Chairman <a href="Bob%20Menendez">Bob Menendez</a> (D-NJ) said, "The Strategic Competition Act of 2021 is a recognition that this moment demands a unified, strategic response that can rebuild American leadership, invest in our ability to out-compete China, and reground diplomacy in our core values", adding "The United States government must be clear-eyed and sober about Beijing's intentions and actions, and calibrate our policy and strategy accordingly."
In May 2021, the Strategic Competition Act of 2021 was consolidated into a larger bill, the <a href="United%20States%20Innovation%20and%20Competition%20Act">United States Innovation and Competition Act</a> (USICA), authorizing for basic and advanced technology research over a five year period. In June 2021, the USICA passed 68-32 in the Senate with bipartisan support.
Military strategy.
The United States' <a href="Indo-Pacific%23Geopolitical%20context">Indo-Pacific strategy</a> has broadly been to use the surrounding countries around China to blunt its influence. This includes strengthening the bonds between <a href="South%20Korea">South Korea</a> and <a href="Japan">Japan</a> as well as trying to get <a href="India">India</a>, another large developing country to help with their efforts. Additionally, with the <a href="Intermediate-Range%20Nuclear%20Forces%20Treaty%23US%20withdrawal%20and%20termination">US withdrawal</a> from the <a href="Intermediate-Range%20Nuclear%20Forces%20Treaty">Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces Treaty</a> with <a href="Russia">Russia</a> (in part because China wasn't a party to it), the US has reportedly wanted to find a host in the Asia-Pacific region to point the previously banned weapons at China. In addition to <a href="soft%20power">soft power</a> diplomacy within the region, the US is physically surrounding China with <a href="list%20of%20United%20States%20military%20bases">military bases</a> in the event of any conflict. The United States has developed many military bases in the Asia Pacific equipped with <a href="warship">warship</a>s, <a href="nuclear%20missile">nuclear missile</a>s and nuclear-capable <a href="strategic%20bomber">strategic bomber</a>s as a deterrent and to achieve <a href="full%20spectrum%20dominance">full spectrum dominance</a> in a strategy similar to that of the Cold War.
Sanctions.
The use of <a href="United%20States%20sanctions">economic sanctions</a> has always been a tool of American foreign policy and has become used more frequently in the 21st century, from targeting individuals and sometimes whole countries by using the centrality of the <a href="Banking%20in%20the%20United%20States">US financial system</a> and the position of the <a href="US%20dollar">US dollar</a> as the world's <a href="reserve%20currency">reserve currency</a> to limit trade and cashflow.
Xinjiang.
In the area of <a href="human%20rights">human rights</a> and <a href="international%20law">international law</a>, the U.S. has worked to put pressure on China internationally by drawing attention to its human rights record. In particular, U.S. policymakers have focused on the status of China's "<a href="Xinjiang%20re-education%20camps">re-education camps</a>" for those accused of <a href="Islamic%20extremism">religious extremism</a> in China's <a href="Xinjiang%20Autonomous%20Region">Xinjiang Autonomous Region</a>, the region inhabited by the Muslim <a href="Uyghurs">Uyghur minority</a>, as well as the <a href="2019%E2%80%9320%20Hong%20Kong%20protests">protests in Hong Kong</a>. These camps, which some NGOs such as the Washington-based <a href="Victims%20of%20Communism%20Memorial%20Foundation">Victims of Communism Memorial Foundation</a> and <a href="East%20Turkistan%20National%20Awakening%20Movement">East Turkistan National Awakening Movement</a> estimated to have a population of over one million people, have been described as "indoctrination camps" that are reportedly run like prisons to eradicate Uyghur culture and religion in an attempt at <a href="Sinicization">Sinicization</a> as well as likened to <a href="concentration%20camps">concentration camps</a> in the early days of <a href="Nazi%20Germany">Nazi Germany</a>. The <a href="United%20States%20Congress">United States Congress</a> has responded to these reports with calls for the imposition of sanctions under the <a href="Magnitsky%20Act">Global Magnitsky Human Rights Accountability Act</a>; in December 2019, the <a href="United%20States%20House%20of%20Representatives">House of Representatives</a> and <a href="United%20States%20Senate">Senate</a> passed the <a href="Uighur%20Human%20Rights%20Policy%20Act">Uighur Human Rights Policy Act</a>.
Chinese officials have responded to the criticism and scrutiny by rejecting the "more than one million" camp population estimate by foreign experts and say the "vocational education centers" in Xinjiang are for preventing religious extremism by teaching <a href="Mandarin%20Chinese">Mandarin</a> and job skills and cast doubt on the reports as "maliciously distorting and slandering" China's counter-terrorism and de-radicalization efforts. At an event at the <a href="U.N.%20Human%20Rights%20Council">U.N. Human Rights Council</a> session in <a href="Geneva">Geneva</a>, a spokesperson at China's Bureau of Human Rights Affairs of the <a href="State%20Council%20Information%20Office">State Council Information Office</a> told reporters that "if you do not say it's the best way, maybe it's the necessary way to deal with Islamic or religious extremism, because <a href="Western%20world">the West</a> has failed in doing so, in dealing with religious Islamic extremism", and dismissed the view that Xinjiang's surveillance create a <a href="martial%20law">martial law</a> environment, saying "as to surveillance, China is learning from the <a href="United%20Kingdom">UK</a>... your <a href="per%20capita">per capita</a> <a href="closed-circuit%20television">CCTV</a> is much higher than that for China's Xinjiang Autonomous Region."
Hong Kong.
As has been the case in the past with other adversarial countries, some pro-Chinese commentators argue that the US has allegedly taken advantage of cleavages and <a href="regionalism%20%28politics%29">regionalism</a> within the PRC and the <a href="One%20Country%20Two%20Systems">One Country Two Systems</a> framework to <a href="divide%20and%20rule%23Foreign%20Policy">divide and conquer</a>, particularly in <a href="Xinjiang">Xinjiang</a>, <a href="Tibet">Tibet</a> and <a href="Hong%20Kong">Hong Kong</a>, through the promotion of western democratic institutions. They criticized "US meddling in domestic affairs" when a <a href="2019%20Hong%20Kong%20extradition%20bill">controversial extradition bill</a> was introduced in the <a href="Hong%20Kong%20SAR">Hong Kong SAR</a>, sparking the <a href="2019%E2%80%9320%20Hong%20Kong%20protests">2019–20 Hong Kong protests</a>. Beijing accused the US of domestic interference by allegedly backing a particularly violent contingent of protesters wearing black masks through the <a href="government-organized%20non-governmental%20organization">US government-funded</a> <a href="National%20Endowment%20for%20Democracy">National Endowment for Democracy</a>. Although the US denies the allegations of interference, pro-Chinese elements nevertheless maintained such view, stating that US diplomats have been photographed meeting with the protesters and lawmakers have hosted multiple protest leaders in Washington and voiced public support for the protesters' demands, and saying that the "One-Country, Two-Systems" arrangement should be honored.
Economic strategy.
With China <a href="China%20and%20the%20World%20Trade%20Organization">entering</a> the <a href="World%20Trade%20Organization">World Trade Organization</a> in 2001 with approval from the US, China and the world economy benefited from <a href="globalization">globalization</a> and the access to new markets and the increased trade that resulted. Despite this, some in the United States lament letting China in the WTO because part of the motivation to do so, the political liberalization of the PRC's government along the lines of the <a href="Washington%20Consensus">Washington Consensus</a> never materialized. The US hoped economic liberalization would eventually lead to political liberalization to a government more akin to the then recently repatriated <a href="Hong%20Kong%20Special%20Administrative%20Region">Hong Kong Special Administrative Region</a> under <a href="One%20country%2C%20two%20systems">One country, two systems</a>.
Trans-Pacific Partnership.
In part, the <a href="Trans-Pacific%20Partnership">Trans-Pacific Partnership</a> (TPP), <a href="geopolitical">geopolitical</a>ly was thought by some to likely bring China's neighbours closer to the United States and reduce its economic leverage and dependence on Chinese trade. If ratified, the TPP would have strengthened American influence on future rules for the global economy. <a href="US%20Secretary%20of%20Defense">US Secretary of Defense</a> <a href="Ash%20Carter">Ash Carter</a> claimed the passage of the TPP to be as valuable to the United States as the creation of another <a href="aircraft%20carrier">aircraft carrier</a>. President Barack Obama has argued "if we don't pass this agreement—if America doesn't write those rules—then countries like China will".
On January 23, 2017, the newly elected <a href="President%20Donald%20Trump">President Donald Trump</a> formally <a href="Trans-Pacific%20Partnership%23United%20States%20withdrawal">withdrew the United State</a>s from the Trans-Pacific Partnership.
Trade War.
In what would become the <a href="China%E2%80%93United%20States%20trade%20war">China–United States trade war</a>, President Donald Trump began setting <a href="tariffs">tariffs</a> and other <a href="trade%20barriers">trade barriers</a> on China in 2018 with the goal of forcing it to make changes to what the U.S. says are "unfair trade practices". The US says those trade practices and their effects are the growing <a href="trade%20deficit">trade deficit</a>, the theft of <a href="intellectual%20property">intellectual property</a> and the forced transfer of American technology to China. Jeff Spross, an economics and business correspondent at <a href="The%20Week">TheWeek.com</a>, commented that China is pursuing economic development much in the same way as many other modern industrialized economies before it, except in a world where the rules of the global <a href="free%20trade">free trade</a> order are enforced by institutions like the <a href="World%20Bank">World Bank</a>, the <a href="International%20Monetary%20Fund">International Monetary Fund</a>, and the <a href="World%20Trade%20Organization">World Trade Organization</a>, ensuring economic development is driven by private investors.
At the <a href="Bretton%20Woods%20Conference">Bretton Woods Conference</a>, the US representative, <a href="Harry%20Dexter%20White">Harry Dexter White</a>, insisted that the world <a href="reserve%20currency">reserve currency</a> be the <a href="United%20States%20dollar">United States dollar</a> instead of a proposed new international unit of currency and that the IMF and World Bank be under the purview of the United States. The <a href="Reagan%20administration">Reagan administration</a> and US Trade Representative <a href="Robert%20Lighthizer">Robert Lighthizer</a>, and Donald Trump as a private citizen, made identical claims in the 1980s when Japan was undergoing its <a href="economic%20miracle">economic miracle</a> which led Japan to signing the <a href="Plaza%20Accord">Plaza Accord</a>. Like the TPP, it has been argued that the trade war is simply a more direct attempt to stifle China's development and is indicative of a shift in the US public perception of China as a "rival nation to be contained and beaten" among the two major political parties in Congress, the general public and even the business sector. It has been argued however that employing the Cold War playbook for the seemingly destined-to-fail <a href="Soviet%20Union">Soviet Union</a>, a <a href="social%20ownership">state-run</a> and largely <a href="closed%20economy">closed economy</a> will not work in the case of China because of its sheer size, growing wealth and vibrant economy. To halt development progress, particularly the <a href="Made%20in%20China%202025">Made in China 2025</a> plan, the US has responded by making it harder for Chinese <a href="tech%20companies">tech companies</a> from obtaining US technologies by investing in or acquiring US tech companies, and even attempting to stifle specific companies, namely <a href="Huawei">Huawei</a>, <a href="ZTE">ZTE</a> and <a href="ByteDance">ByteDance</a>, from doing business domestically and abroad allegedly due to unspecified or speculative national security risks. With senior Trump administration officials such as <a href="John%20Bolton">John Bolton</a>, <a href="Peter%20Navarro">Peter Navarro</a> and Robert Lightizer demanding any comprehensive trade deal feature "structural changes" which would essentially entail China surrendering its sovereignty over its <a href="socialist%20market%20economy">economic system</a> and planning (its Made in China 2025 industrial plan) and permanently ceding technology leadership to the US-an untenable situation to the Chinese- some see trade tensions continuing long into the future.
In the face of the US tariffs in the trade war and the <a href="International%20sanctions%20during%20the%20Russo-Ukrainian%20War">sanctions on Russia</a> following the <a href="annexation%20of%20Crimea%20by%20the%20Russian%20Federation">annexation of Crimea</a>, <a href="Sino-Russian%20relations%20since%201991">China and Russia</a> have cultivated closer economic ties as well as security and defense cooperation to offset the losses.
Belt and Road Initiative.
Another high-profile debate among some people in the United States and China on the international stage is the observation about China's growing geopolitical footprint in "<a href="soft%20power">soft power</a> diplomacy" and <a href="development%20finance%20institution">international development finance</a>. Particularly, this surrounds China's <a href="Belt%20and%20Road%20Initiative">Belt and Road Initiative</a> (formerly "One Belt, One Road"), which has been labeled as "aggressive" and "<a href="Debt-trap%20diplomacy">debt trap diplomacy</a>", with the latter referring to the sale of an interest in a 99-year lease by <a href="Sri%20Lanka">Sri Lanka</a> in the <a href="Port%20of%20Hambantota">Port of Hambantota</a> to a Chinese <a href="state-owned%20company">state-owned company</a> after Sri Lanka had <a href="default%20%28finance%29">default</a>ed on a loan to develop the port.
Some commentators say that China is utilizing and selling the expertise it has gained in <a href="poverty%20alleviation">poverty alleviation</a> and <a href="infrastructure">infrastructure</a> <a href="Construction%23Infrastructure%20construction">building</a> used in its own modernization experience to other <a href="developing%20countries">developing countries</a>. A study conducted by the <a href="Daniel%20H.%20Rosen">Rhodium Group</a> found only one case of <a href="asset%20seizure">asset seizure</a>, the oft-cited <a href="Hambantota%20Port">Hambantota Port</a> in <a href="Sri%20Lanka">Sri Lanka</a>, saying that China is more likely to restructure or <a href="write-off">write-off</a> the debt.
Strategic alliances.
US–Japan–Australia.
Then-U.S. secretary of state <a href="Condoleezza%20Rice">Condoleezza Rice</a> visited <a href="Australia">Australia</a> in March 2006 for the "trilateral security forum" with the <a href="Japan">Japan</a>ese foreign minister <a href="Taro%20Aso">Taro Aso</a> and his Australian counterpart <a href="Alexander%20Downer">Alexander Downer</a>.
US–Japan–Australia–India (the "Quad").
In May 2007, the four nations signed a strategic military partnership agreement, the <a href="Quadrilateral%20Security%20Dialogue">Quadrilateral Security Dialogue</a>.
US–Japan–India.
The three nations held their first trilateral meeting in December 2011.
US–Taiwan (ROC).
Although the United States recognized the People's Republic of China in 1979, the US maintains "de facto" diplomatic relations and is bound to it by the <a href="Taiwan%20Relations%20Act">Taiwan Relations Act</a>, which <a href="policy%20of%20deliberate%20ambiguity%23Taiwan">ambiguously</a> states, "the United States will make available to Taiwan such defense articles and defense services in such quantity as may be necessary to enable Taiwan to maintain a sufficient self-defense capabilities".
Previously, the United States recognized the Republic of China as the sole legitimate government of China despite the loss of the territory during the <a href="Chinese%20Civil%20War">Chinese Civil War</a>. In 1954, the US and the ROC on Taiwan (Formosa) signed the <a href="Sino-American%20Mutual%20Defense%20Treaty">Sino-American Mutual Defense Treaty</a>, which essentially prevented the <a href="People%27s%20Liberation%20Army">People's Liberation Army</a> from taking over the island of Taiwan. During the Cold War, the treaty prolonged and assisted the Republic of China in maintaining legitimacy as the sole government of the whole of mainland China until the early 1970s and also helped US policymakers to shape the policy of containment in East Asia together with South Korea and Japan against the spread of communism. In 1980, the treaty was abrogated after the US normalized relations with the PRC.
The recent decade has seen an increasing frequency of <a href="List%20of%20US%20arms%20sales%20to%20Taiwan">US arms sales to Taiwan</a> alongside expanding commercial ties. On December 16, 2015, the Obama administration announced a deal to sell $1.83 billion worth of arms to the <a href="Republic%20of%20China%20Armed%20Forces">Armed Forces of Taiwan</a>, a year and eight months after U.S. Congress passed the Taiwan Relations Act Affirmation and Naval Vessel Transfer Act of 2014 to allow the sale of Oliver Hazard Perry-class frigates to Taiwan. The deal would include the sale of two decommissioned U.S. Navy frigates, anti-tank missiles, Assault Amphibious Vehicles, and FIM-92 Stinger surface-to-air missiles, amid the territorial disputes in the South China Sea.
A new $250 million compound for the <a href="American%20Institute%20in%20Taiwan">American Institute in Taiwan</a> was unveiled in June 2018, accompanied by a "low-key" American delegation. The Chinese authorities denounced this action as violation of the "one China" policy statement and demanded the US to stop all relations with Taiwan without intercession of China. In 2019, the US approved the sale of 108 <a href="M1A2%20Abrams">M1A2 Abrams</a> tanks and 250 Stinger missiles for $2.2 billion and 66 F-16V fighter jets for $8 million. With the sale, China vowed to sanction any companies involved in the transactions. In May 2020, the U.S. Department of State approved a possible <a href="Foreign%20Military%20Sales">Foreign Military Sales</a> of 18 <a href="Mark%2048%20torpedo">MK-48 Mod 6 Advanced Technology heavy weight torpedoes</a> for Taiwan in a deal estimated to cost $180 million.
US–Philippines.
The relationship between the United States and the Philippines has historically been strong and has been described as a Special Relationship. The 1951 mutual-defense treaty was reaffirmed with the November 2011 Manila Declaration.
US–South Korea.
The US continues to host military bases in South Korea. The Chinese believe the deployment of the US made <a href="Terminal%20High%20Altitude%20Area%20Defense">Terminal High Altitude Area Defense</a> (THAAD) missile system on the peninsula is not for the stated purpose of protecting against a nuclear armed North Korea, but to degrade the PLA Rocket Force from carrying out a nuclear second strike in the event of a war with the United States. South Korea's decision to deploy the system led to a significant deterioration in <a href="China%E2%80%93South%20Korea%20relations%23Deployment%20of%20THAAD%20in%20South%20Korea">China–South Korea relations</a>
Challenges.
Australia.
<a href="Australia">Australia</a> has a growing dependency on China's market. Its <a href="mining%20in%20Australia">mining industry</a> is booming owing to Chinese demand. During the <a href="Presidency%20of%20George%20W.%20Bush">second Bush administration</a>, ahead of the visit by <a href="United%20States%20Secretary%20of%20State">Secretary of State</a> <a href="Condoleezza%20Rice">Condoleezza Rice</a> and her warning about China becoming a "negative force" the Australian <a href="Foreign%20Affairs%20Minister">Foreign Affairs Minister</a>, <a href="Alexander%20Downer">Alexander Downer</a>, warned that Australia does not agree with a policy of containment of China. Rice clarified that the U.S. is not advocating a containment policy.
India.
<a href="India">India</a> is a founding member of the <a href="Non%20Aligned%20Movement">Non Aligned Movement</a>, a group of mostly developing states that are not formally aligned with or against any major <a href="power%20bloc">power bloc</a> which has among its five pillars "mutual non-aggression", "mutual non-interference in domestic affairs", and "peaceful co-existence". The basis of the Non Aligned Movement is based on the principles in a 1954 agreement on <a href="China%E2%80%93India%20relations">China–India relations</a>, the <a href="Five%20Principles%20of%20Peaceful%20Coexistence">Five Principles of Peaceful Coexistence</a>.
China is India's largest trading partner. <a href="George%20W.%20Bush">George W. Bush</a>'s visit to India was seen in part as an attempt to boost bilateral trade and to expand US influence, by offering India important <a href="nuclear%20technology">nuclear technology</a>. China is the US's fifth-largest trading partner in terms of exports, but India ranks only twenty-fourth.
Japan.
China has overtaken the US as <a href="Japan">Japan</a>'s largest trading partner.
Philippines.
Under President <a href="Rodrigo%20Duterte">Rodrigo Duterte</a>, the <a href="Philippines">Philippines</a> has cultivated closer ties to China and has tried to compartmentalize the <a href="territorial%20disputes%20in%20the%20South%20China%20Sea">South China Sea territorial issues</a> from the broader relationship. In a speech in July 2019, President Duterte claimed that the United States has been trying to use the Philippines as "bait" to ignite regional conflict and confrontation with China regarding incidents in the <a href="South%20China%20Sea">South China Sea</a>, "egging" him to take military action against China and pledging US support through the mutual defense obligations. To this idea he sarcastically said, "if America wants China to leave, and I can't make them... I want the whole <a href="7th%20Fleet">7th Fleet</a> of the armed forces of the United States of America there... when they enter the South China Sea, I will enter." He added, "what do you think Filipinos are, earthworms?... now, I say, you bring your planes, your boats to South China Sea. Fire the first shot, and we are just here behind you. Go ahead, let's fight."
South Korea.
China is <a href="South%20Korea">South Korea</a>'s biggest trading partner, with trade with China making up 25.1% of its exports and 20.5% of its imports.
